Oumi Nishi, Kazuhiro IIYAMA, Chisa YASUNAGA-AOKI, Susumu
SHIMIZU
Title:
Comparison of the germination speed of conidia in hot and
cold conditions from eight species of the entomopathogenic fungus
Metarhizium spp. from Japan
Keywords:
entomopathogenic fungi habitat, Metarhizium, phylogenetic
analysis, physiological characteristics, thermal condition
Abstract:
The knowledge of growth characteristics of
entomopathogenic fungi at different temperatures are of great importance
for understanding their field efficacy as biopesticides and ecology. Two
genotypes with different habitat preferences, which were also related to
the physiological characteristics at different temperatures and UV
levels, have been reported for Metarhizium anisopliae sensu lato in
eastern Canada. However, the relationship between their DNA-based
phylogenetic tree classifications and growth characteristics at
different temperatures was not investigated adequately. In this study,
we compared the phylogenetic relationships between M. anisopliae sensu
lato isolates from soils in various environments and the germination
speed of their conidia on agar medium in hot and cold conditions. The
results showed that the germination speeds of isolates belonging to the
clades of M. brunneum and M. flavoviride var. pemphigi were faster at
lower temperatures (9.7â“11.0Â°C) and slower at higher temperatures
(34.3â“35.2Â°C) compared with the other isolates. The isolates of these
two species originated from different geographical regions in Japan,
despite their uniform growth characteristics, and had polymorphisms in a
part of the DNA sequence of translation elongation factor 1-alpha. The
results suggest that these two species may have better field efficacy as
biopesticides in cooler environments.
